titlestmt.titleproper: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, Program Office, Series 26
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, Program Office, Series 26 FA1205

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-10-01 02:03:12 -0400.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, Program Office, Series 26

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of the RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as governor of New York from January 1, 1959, to December 18, 1973. He was the first person elected to four consecutive four-year terms as a state governor.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edgar D. Draper served as Program Associate in New York State Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's Executive Chamber. He also represented the state of New York as a delegate at several meeting for the Interstate Compact for Education and its governing body, the Education Commission of the States.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series contains office files of Edgar D. Draper. They document official activities in the execution of his duties as a member of Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occurred in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Nelson A. Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.

This series documents the activities of New York State Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's Program Office. It was created by Edgar D. Draper, who served as Program Associate in Rockefeller's Executive Chamber. The contents of the series predominately concern education reform and development as well as national trends in Republican Party politics. Material formats include correspondence, memoranda, reports, press releases, pamphlets, newspaper clippings, state and federal legislative bills, and transcripts of speeches and public addresses. In addition to Mr. Draper, correspondents found within the series include Secretary to the Governor William J. Ronan, Executive Officer to the Governor Alton G. Marshall, Commissioner of Education James E. Allen Jr., and Deputy Commissioner of Education Ewald B. Nyquist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged into 7 subseries. The subseries arrangement is as follows:

did.unittitle: Political files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The contents of the subseries primarily pertain to Nelson A. Rockefeller's political record and achievements as New York State Governor, the tensions and shifts within the Republican Party at the time of the 1964 Presidential Election, Rockefeller's meetings with New York town and county community leaders, and Rockefeller's discontinued run for the Republican Party nomination in the 1964 election. General political records include the correspondence of Program Associate Edgar D. Draper, lists of commitments made by Rockefeller in regards to the activities of various state programs, and transcripts of speeches and interviews by Rockefeller and other individuals. Many of the records discuss the relationship between the Republican Party and the African American community in connection to the Civil Rights Movement and the Republican Party's 1964 presidential candidate, Arizona Senator Barry Goldwater. The subseries includes a transcript of a public statement by Rockefeller in which he discusses the outcome of the election and calls for a constructive rebuilding of the party. Materials related to Rockefeller's various town and county visits throughout the state of New York include memoranda, schedules, lists of key community leaders, and reports providing background information and points of local interest for each meeting location. These documents are loosely organized by the town or county they concern. Records related to Rockefeller's run for Republican Party presidential nominee include correspondence, reports, statements, and pamphlets as well other miscellaneous campaign materials. Several documents originate from the campaigns of other nomination candidates as well as from the larger Republican Party platform. Lastly, the subseries contains a small amount of documents related to John V. Lindsay's campaign for New York City Mayor in 1965.

NAR town meetings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Towns and counties represented within this file include:

1) Harlem; 2) Brooklyn; 3) Queens; 4) The Bronx; 5) City of Buffalo and Niagara and Erie Counties; 6) City of Syracuse and Onondaga County; 7) City of Utica and Oneida County; 8) Jamestown and Olean; 9) Albany; 10) City of Plattsburgh and Clinton County. Other miscellaneous towns and counties are also represented within the file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: NAR town meetings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Towns and counties represented within this file include:

1) St. Lawrence County; 2) Harlem; 3) Cortland and Tompkins Counties; 4) Montgomery, Fulton, and Monroe Counties; 5) Auburn, Newark, and Geneva; 6) Oswego and Jefferson Counties; 7) City of New York and Duchess and Ulster Counties; 7) Saratoga Springs and Glen Falls. Other miscellaneous towns and counties are also represented within the file.

did.unittitle: NAR town meetings briefings
NAR United States presidential campaign correspondence and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a letter addressed from Edgar D. Draper to retired Baseball player Jackie Robinson. The letter discusses the comments of several African American participants on David Susskind's television program "Open End" about the Republican Party. Draper asks Robinson if he thinks it is advisable to arrange a meeting where they can discuss suggested Republican Party outreach to the African American community. Robinson served as one of Nelson A. Rockefeller's national campaign directors for the 1964 Presidential Election.

did.unittitle: NAR United States presidential campaign statements, brochures, and other promotional materials
Education files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents matters related to New York State funding for education as well as to attempts at education reform and development by Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's Executive Chamber, the New York State Education Department, and other local, state, and national organizations concerned with education policy and institutions. Much of the education reform discussed in the subseries involves expansion of education opportunities to minority and disadvantaged populations, increased medical and health professional training in response to the state's Medicaid program, and improved programs for science and technology learning. Several files concern state and national education policy in a broad sense. These files include correspondence, reports, and other materials related to legislation and performance of state education programs, background information on the proposed Pennsylvania Plan property tax law, and multistate collaboration on education policy through the activities of the Interstate Compact for Education. A large part of the subseries specifically pertains to higher education policy and development with a particular focus on funding for the City University of New York. These materials include transcripts of addresses by various education and city officials before a Joint Legislative Committee on Education on March 22, 1966, CUNY budget information, correspondence concerning Rockefeller's support for the City University Supplementary Aid and Construction Bill, and a number of draft letters Program Associate Edgar D. Draper created when preparing Rockefeller's official responses to calls for greater state aid to CUNY. This subseries also includes tabulations of monetary amounts distributed by the state for college scholarships in the academic years 1958-1959 and 1964-1965.

Interstate Compact for Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents the involvement of Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's administration in the origins and activities of the Interstate Compact for Education and its governing body, the Education Commission of the States. Much of the content found within the subseries pertains to different planning, interim, and annual meetings of the Compact and Commission. These records primarily consist of conference programs, reports, lists of attendees, meeting minutes, agendas, transcripts of addresses, and promotional materials related to both the actual meetings and the cities that hosted the meetings. The subseries also contains correspondence, press clippings, and transcripts of public speeches that relate to the Compact in a broader sense. The correspondence compiled by Rockefeller's Program Associate, Edgar D. Draper, chiefly concerns the list of delegates Rockefeller selected to represent the state of New York at different meetings of the Education Commission of the States. Lastly, the subseries contains several copies of the Compact for Education summary, copies of the Compact's Enabling Act, copies of New York State legislative bills related to the state joining the Compact, a copy of the Education Commission of the States Bylaws, and drafts and copies of other resolutions passed by the Compact.

did.unittitle: General correspondence
Compact for Education Enabling Act and bills for New York State adoption
Education Commission of the States Bylaws and other Compact for Education resolutions
Education Commission of the States publications and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains three publications printed by the Education Commission of the States:

1) "Power Play for Control of Education" - a copy of the edited proceedings of the Commission's 1967 Annual Meeting; 2) Vol.1 No.7 of "Compact" - a monthly journal publication by the Commission; 3) "Seven Critical Issues in Education: Alternatives for State Action" - a collection of papers discussing education problems.

This file also includes one summary report published by the New York State Department of Education about a multistate education conference that was titled "To Strengthen State-Local Relationships in Urban Education". Other types of documents such as correspondence and newspaper clippings were originally interspersed throughout the publications. They are currently housed with the publications with which they were originally attached.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains duplicates of items primarily found within the file "Compact for Education Enabling Act and bills for New York State adoption" as well as miscellaneous documents not found within the rest of the subseries. These documents chiefly relate to the operations of the Compact.

did.unittitle: Long-Range Program Planning submissions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a small group of Long-Range Program Plans submitted by the New York State Commission for Human Rights, the New York State Education Department, and the New York State Division for Youth. According to the Guidelines and Instructions for Preparation of Long-Range Program Planning Submissions, agencies were required to compile this data in order to assist the New York State Division of the Budget in determining annual budget needs and in identifying the long-term impact of State programs. The Guidelines identify the expansion of state government and the developments in federal assistance programs as reasons for the need of a more systematic approach by the State in coordinating the program plans of individual agencies. A copy of these Guidelines, prepared by the Division of the Budget, is included with the subseries. Not all plans appear to be complete, but their individual components have been grouped together in the files in order to represent their contextual relationship.

did.unittitle: Division of the Budget guidelines for Long-Range Program Planning submissions

did.unittitle: Program planning preparations and follow-up

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records within this subseries chiefly pertain to the development of New York State government long-term program planning, the planning processes of different State agencies, and the program planning follow-up documentation and measures prepared by Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's Program Associate Edgar D. Draper and other State staff members. Draper's copy of a program planning follow-up log is included. Handwritten notes have been added to this copy as well as correspondence concerning a follow-up program related to public educational television and the hearings for the 1965 Long-Range Program Planning submissions of the New York State Division for Youth, the New York State Education Department, and the New York State Commission for Human Rights. Other follow-up correspondence and reports included within the subseries pertains to a follow-up program about recruitment and training for professional State jobs.

did.unittitle: Materials related to Long-Range Program Planning preparations
Program Planning Follow-up log
Program Planning Follow-up correspondence and reports
Program Planning Follow-up correspondence and reports
Federal legislation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains copies of federal legislative bills. These bills concern such subjects as education, school prayer, youth employment and delinquency, voting rights and other civil rights matters, hospital insurance, physical and mental health, manpower development, area redevelopment, poverty, Appalachia, and library services. Handwritten notes have been added to several of the bills.

did.unittitle: Bills
Bills
Bills
Bills
Conference materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials found within this subseries pertain to a number of regional, state, and national conferences as well as to the different social, education, economic, and political subjects those conferences concerned. In the course of his duties as Program Associate for Nelson A. Rockefeller's Executive Chamber, Edgar D. Draper attended several of the conferences documented in the subseries. He also worked with other State government staff to prepare background information for Rockefeller's participation at other conferences and to help organize conferences set up by the State and Rockefeller's administration. Files in the subseries primarily pertain to individual conferences, but there are a few that group together documents concerning a number of different conferences on a particular theme such as industry. Common material formats found within the subseries include correspondence, invitations, schedules, programs, press clippings, and reports.
